refnamediv.refpurpose: Adds the applicable facts of the graph into a rule set.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This function associates a rule-name with a source named graphs identified by a named graph IRI. This named graph is contains RDF statements that constitute the desired inference rule to be created. You can use this procedure to add RDF statements from other named graphs as part as part of a rule-enhancement effort.

refsect2.title: rule_name
refsect2.para: Rule name (literal that identifies the rule).

refsect2.title: graph_iri
refsect2.para: A named graph IRI that identifies the source of RDF statements to be used as inference rules,

refsect2.title: remove
refsect2.para: (0|1 default 0) - where 1 indicates that the specified graph is to be removed from the rule set.

example.title: Simple Usage Example
example.para: Google and Bloomberg Stock Quote Services return HTML5+Microdata based Linked Open Data using terms from Schema.org. As will be quite common, there is a case sensitive issue in regards to the HTTP URIs that identify the "Financial Quote" class. For Bloomberg we have: <http://schema.org/intangible/financialquote> and for Google: <http://schema.org/Intangible/FinancialQuote> . What follows in an owl:equivalentProperty relation that enables a processor of this data (e.g., SPARQL Query Processor) apply reasoning and inference based on the semantics of the owl:equivalentProperty relation. Using Virtuoso's SPARQL processor, you can create an inference rule declaratively via rdfs_rule_set():

example.title: Create Rule example
